Topic.Title: JPM 9 billion loss could double in two weeks.

Message.Msg: Yes JPM loss will double to $20 Billion easily and they will report it as a $5 billion problem. Yes Apple will go down because they are simply an electronics manufacturing company that has some interesting work conditions and now they are telling the American people that they can't buy any competitor's products with that Samsung ruling. It's like an airplane, it may fly missing three bolts and it may fly missing four bolts but that fifth bolt can be the catalyst to fail the whole system. Apple could be losing a bolt with their shameless exploitation of the consumer thinking they will discard their electronic product every year to buy the new one, I believe they will get tired of it. Another bolt is their shameless exploitation of their employees by paying them little when it comes to the grand scheme of how much they earn. Another bolt can be the arrogance of making a whole line of products that can't be recycled. Another bolt can be that even companies that don't have an electronics product history are now getting into the game i.e. Amazon. Another bolt could have been the loss of Jobs. There will be a point where the fifth bolt falls out and then look out below. No positions at the moment.

Message.Title: "I don’t think an iPad Mini is on the way to the public in the near future."
Message.Msg: Their profit is based round their hardware – a model that neither Amazon or Google are relying on with their small tablets. Even with their legendary grip on the supply chain I don’t see them extracting enough value unless the unit is priced at a minimum of $299, which puts it rather close to the base iPad 2 unit.Once more, it’s time to discuss Apple, so once more I’ll invoke Taniyama-Shimura and look at the world of the seven inch tablet and the iPad. When it was Steve Jobs running Apple it was easy. Jobs would say that something was silly, impossible, and a bad decision, until the moment that Apple announced a product that would revolutionise that area of technology. After some investigation, it will turn out that Apple has been working on said technology for a few years, internally iterating like crazy to get the perfect product. With all the talk of a 7 inch tablet I keep coming back to Steve Jobs dissing the 7 inch form factor when talking about the iPad. Given Apple’s previous form, that leads me to think that seven inches is bad… until seven inches is what consumers need. Strictly speaking, all the talk is now over a 7.85 inch tablet thanks to some nifty arithmetical calculations around display panels and pixel density (here’s Andy Faust’s explanation). This ‘mythical’ iPad Mini is an interesting test for CEO Tim Cook. Thanks to Google’s Nexus 7 the smaller form factor is gathering a huge amount of media love, although it remains to be seen if it is something that will translate into significant sales in the marketplace. Amazon’s Kindle Fire is probably the leading 7 inch tablet, with Samsung’s smaller Tab devices flying the flag outside of the American market. The issue that Cook will need to address is simple – does he start the production of the iPad Mini this year? To have any significant volume for the holiday season the decision needs to be made now. Can they let Amazon continue to build a presence and brand name in the 7 inch space, presumably with a Kindle Fire mk 2 on the way? Should they let Google demonstrate to their partners how to go about making smaller Android tablets with the Nexus 7? Apple are a conservative company, and if you assume an iPhone 5 is on the way it makes more sense to concentrate on the smartphone now, and keep an iPad Mini for the traditional ‘iPad announcement’ date in March. I’ve no doubt that Apple have a 7.85 inch tablet inside Cupertino. I suspect they have iOS devices with a variety of screen sizes, all being constantly tested and evaluated. Will any of them make it to the public before the end of the year? On balance I don’t think an iPad Mini is on the way to the public in the near future. ==================

Topic.Title: iPhone 5 will power by Samsung quad-core processor.---- Yes, the same Exynos quad-core processor powers the Samsung Galaxy S3.

Message.Msg: the processor is just manufactured by samsung as was the one in the original iPhone, the iPhone 3G and the iPhone 3GS. however, all the design work is from ARM Holdings and is based specifically on the ARM Cortex-A15 MPCore and ARMv7 cpu chip set. Samsung is merely a licensee of the design. the ARMv7 design is the direct descendant of the ARMv6. ironically, the complete ARMv6 architecture and the creation of ARM Holdings is the result of joint design work of 3 companies: acorn, vlsi and apple... so again, samsung is just manufacturing apple's design. the only new here is it is actually legal... lol.

Topic.Title: iPhone 5 will power by Samsung quad-core processor.---- Yes, the same Exynos quad-core processor powers the Samsung Galaxy S3.

Message.Msg: It is expected that the iPhone 5 will ship with a quad-core ARM chip that "uses Samsung’s Exynos 4 architecture" Samsung’s existing Exynos 4 Quad chip (4412) is a Cortex-A9 running at 1.4GHz and using a Mali-400 quad-core GPU. Apple will obviously tweak that to suit its needs. Moving to 4 cores would be a first for Apple, as the new iPad stuck to a dual-core design and beefed up the on-board GPU. A quad-core chip in the iPhone 5 would also likely share a similar GPU upgrade, meaning the handset promises to be an incredibly fast device. Of course, Apple can ensure iOS takes full advantage of all four cores, but app developers will likely have to update their apps to use the extra performance on offer. It does bode very well for games though, and would yet again show how quickly smartphones are catching up to dedicated gaming handhelds like the 3DS and PS Vita. A phone that’s 7.9mm thick, has a 4-inch 16:9 display, and is powered by a quad-core processor and upgraded GPU sounds like a very desirable handset. And that’s before you stick the iPhone name on it. not 100% the same quad-core ARM if so like you say why aapl manufacturing on their own IC manufacture they just bought not long ago ?

Topic.Title: read asymco "building and dismantling windows"... very scare for msft
read asymco "building and dismantling windows"... very scare for msft

Message.Msg: in 2 year ? you talking about unit volume. right ? Kindle Fire is no match for the iPad, but the leading online retailer managed to sell nearly 5 million of its portable gadgets over the holidays. Google's Nexus 7 -- matching the Kindle Fire on both price and 7-inch screen size -- will begin shipping as early as next week. The proliferation of 7-inch Android-fueled tablets is hard for Apple to dismiss. After all, this is the one niche where Apple actually commands the lion's share of a growing market. Yes, the iPhone is a bigger contributor to Apple's business at the moment, but roughly two Android smartphones sell for every iPhone that's picked up. Apple's desktops and laptops are still the devices that many consumers associate with the company that until recently was known as Apple Computer, but Apple isn't even one of the world's five largest PC makers by unit volume. That leaves us with the iPod. Apple has had this market cornered for years, but sales of the portable-media player have been falling over the past two years. Apple be Surrounded and Zoom in by the EOY, 2013 Samsung Android Galaxy III Samsung Android Tablet Tab Samsung's Galaxy Note Samsung Windows 8 Phone Samsung Windows 8 Tablets HTC Android phone HTC Android Tablet HTC Windows8 Phone HTC Windows8 Tablet RIM BlackBerry 10 Motorola ATRIX 4G Phone Motorola XOOM Tablet NOK Windows 8 phone Amazon kindle Amazon Phone Google Tablet Google Android phone Facebook Phone Baidu phone Microsoft Surface Table Microsoft Windows8 phone Microsoft Windows8 OEM Tablet (Dell, HP, Asus, Sony, Acer) Windows Phone 8 to start on HTC, Huawei, Nokia and Samsung devices with support for 180 countries May be not one Apple killer, But .... How can Apple keep still able to the same gross without be eating up on profit margin next year?

Again - the loyal APPLE buyer will buy the high-quality product they trust which is APPLE's iPad - Top Brand in the World. A new iPad "Mini" (rumored to be moving into mass-production in September) will serve to LOCK IN the entire market for APPLE - including much of the low-end. Topic.Title: read asymco "building and dismantling windows"... very scare for msft

Message.Msg: Apple is STILL the only company that offers an unmatched umbrella-like ecosystem, where all of your purchased devices work together seamlessly. Some people just don't get it. Yeah, there are an army of devices that one-on-one can match Apple here and there, but as a total package of products across ONE line, Apple has virtually ZERO competition. And that's why they maintain customers at such an amazing clip. And their earnings are proof of that. And I suspect that Apple TV will tie these devices together in such a way that the competition will be further crippled.

Furthermore, many carrier plans are beginning to offer incentives to add a tablet. I believe the iPad Mini will be a Holiday Top Seller. Why?
